questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This process occurs in the mitochondria and involves the oxidation of pyruvate molecules to produce carbon dioxide, NADH, FADH2, and ATP. Name this central metabolic pathway.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This physical quantity represents the product of an object's mass and its velocity. In a closed system, this quantity is conserved. Name this fundamental concept in physics.

questions.subject: IB Analysis and Approaches
questions.question: This theorem states that any continuous function on a closed interval [a, b] is uniformly continuous on that interval. Name this theorem named after a German mathematician.

questions.subject: IB History of the Americas
questions.question: This treaty, signed in 1848, ended the Mexican-American War and ceded a large portion of Mexico's territory to the United States, including present-day California, Arizona, New Mexico, and parts of Utah, Nevada, and Colorado. Name this treaty.

questions.subject: IB Chemistry
questions.question: This law states that the rate of a chemical reaction is directly proportional to the product of the concentrations of the reactants. Name this law named after a French chemist.

questions.subject: IB Economics
questions.question: This economic concept describes a situation where the production of one good increases as the production of another good decreases. Name this phenomenon.

questions.subject: IB English Literature
questions.question: This novel, published in 1847, tells the story of a young governess who is hired to educate the daughter of a wealthy man named Mr. Rochester. Name this classic novel by Charlotte Bronte.

questions.subject: IB Visual Arts
questions.question: This Dutch artist is known for his works such as 'The Starry Night' and 'Sunflowers.' Name this post-impressionist painter.

questions.subject: IB Mathematics: Applications and Interpretation
questions.question: This mathematical concept is used to represent the chance of an event occurring, expressed as a value between 0 and 1. Name this probability measure.

questions.subject: IB Theatre
questions.question: This Greek playwright is known for his tragedies, including 'Oedipus Rex' and 'Antigone.' Name this ancient playwright.

questions.subject: IB Environmental Systems and Societies
questions.question: This biome is characterized by cold temperatures, low biodiversity, and a layer of permanently frozen soil known as permafrost. Name this biome.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This data structure consists of nodes connected in a hierarchical manner. Each node has a parent and zero or more children. Name this data structure.

questions.subject: IB Business Management
questions.question: This management theory emphasizes the importance of dividing labor into specialized tasks to increase efficiency. Name this management theory named after its founder.

questions.subject: IB Psychology
questions.question: This psychological disorder is characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and loss of interest in activities. Name this mood disorder.

questions.subject: IB Design Technology
questions.question: This manufacturing process involves the use of a computer-controlled machine to carve out three-dimensional objects from a solid block of material. Name this process.

questions.subject: IB Music
questions.question: This composer, known for his compositions such as 'Symphony No. 9' and 'Ode to Joy,' is considered one of the greatest composers of all time. Name this German composer.

questions.subject: IB Film
questions.question: This director is known for films such as 'Pulp Fiction,' 'Kill Bill,' and 'Inglourious Basterds.' Name this American filmmaker.

questions.subject: IB World Religions
questions.question: This religion, founded by Siddhartha Gautama, teaches the Four Noble Truths and the Eightfold Path. Name this major world religion.

questions.subject: IB Spanish
questions.question: This Spanish artist, known for his surrealist paintings such as 'The Persistence of Memory,' was born in Figueres, Catalonia. Name this artist.

questions.subject: IB French
questions.question: This French writer is known for novels such as 'Les Misérables' and 'The Hunchback of Notre-Dame.' Name this author.

questions.subject: IB Mandarin
questions.question: This Chinese philosopher, also known as Kongzi, is the central figure in Confucianism. Name this philosopher.

questions.subject: IB Arabic
questions.question: This influential Islamic scholar is known for his comprehensive collection of hadiths, which are sayings and actions of the Prophet Muhammad. Name this scholar.

questions.subject: IB Russian
questions.question: This Russian author is known for novels such as 'War and Peace' and 'Anna Karenina.' Name this prolific writer.

questions.subject: IB Dutch
questions.question: This Dutch artist is known for his works such as 'The Night Watch' and 'The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp.' Name this Dutch painter.

questions.subject: IB German
questions.question: This German composer is known for his compositions such as 'Symphony No. 5' and 'Für Elise.' Name this classical composer.

questions.subject: IB Italian
questions.question: This Italian artist is known for his works such as 'David' and 'The Creation of Adam.' Name this Renaissance artist.

questions.subject: IB Japanese
questions.question: This Japanese filmmaker is known for his films such as 'Seven Samurai' and 'Rashomon.' Name this legendary director.

questions.subject: IB Latin
questions.question: This Roman poet is known for his epic poem 'The Aeneid.' Name this ancient poet.

questions.subject: IB Classical Greek
questions.question: This ancient Greek philosopher is known for his dialogues such as 'The Republic' and 'Apology.' Name this philosopher.

questions.subject: IB Mandarin B
questions.question: This Chinese dynasty, known for its contributions to art, literature, and philosophy, ruled from 1368 to 1644. Name this dynasty.

questions.subject: IB Spanish B
questions.question: This Spanish artist, known for his surrealist paintings such as 'The Persistence of Memory,' was born in Figueres, Catalonia. Name this artist.

questions.subject: IB French B
questions.question: This French artist, known for his impressionist paintings such as 'Impression, Sunrise,' is often regarded as the founder of impressionism. Name this artist.

questions.subject: IB Italian B
questions.question: This Italian sculptor and architect is known for his works such as 'David' and 'Pieta.' Name this Renaissance artist.

questions.subject: IB Japanese B
questions.question: This Japanese novelist is known for his works such as 'Norwegian Wood' and 'Kafka on the Shore.' Name this contemporary author.

questions.subject: IB Latin B
questions.question: This Roman statesman and orator is known for his speeches against the dictator Julius Caesar. Name this Roman politician.

questions.subject: IB Classical Greek B
questions.question: This ancient Greek playwright is known for his tragedies such as 'Oedipus Rex' and 'Antigone.' Name this playwright.

questions.subject: IB Mandarin Ab Initio
questions.question: This Chinese philosopher, also known as Kongzi, is the central figure in Confucianism. Name this philosopher.

questions.subject: IB Spanish Ab Initio
questions.question: This Spanish artist, known for his surrealist paintings such as 'The Persistence of Memory,' was born in Figueres, Catalonia. Name this artist.

questions.subject: IB French Ab Initio
questions.question: This French artist, known for his impressionist paintings such as 'Impression, Sunrise,' is often regarded as the founder of impressionism. Name this artist.

questions.subject: IB Italian Ab Initio
questions.question: This Italian sculptor and architect is known for his works such as 'David' and 'Pieta.' Name this Renaissance artist.

questions.subject: IB Japanese Ab Initio
questions.question: This Japanese novelist is known for his works such as 'Norwegian Wood' and 'Kafka on the Shore.' Name this contemporary author.

questions.subject: IB Latin Ab Initio
questions.question: This Roman statesman and orator is known for his speeches against the dictator Julius Caesar. Name this Roman politician.

questions.subject: IB Classical Greek Ab Initio
questions.question: This ancient Greek playwright is known for his tragedies such as 'Oedipus Rex' and 'Antigone.' Name this playwright.

questions.subject: IB Arabic Ab Initio
questions.question: This influential Islamic scholar is known for his comprehensive collection of hadiths, which are sayings and actions of the Prophet Muhammad. Name this scholar.

questions.subject: IB Russian Ab Initio
questions.question: This Russian author is known for novels such as 'War and Peace' and 'Anna Karenina.' Name this prolific writer.

questions.subject: IB Dutch Ab Initio
questions.question: This Dutch artist is known for his works such as 'The Night Watch' and 'The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp.' Name this Dutch painter.

questions.subject: IB German Ab Initio
questions.question: This German composer is known for his compositions such as 'Symphony No. 5' and 'Für Elise.' Name this classical composer.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: The energy of electromagnetic waves is obtained by multiplying Planck's constant h by this quantity. When an object such as a bridge vibrates at the natural state of this quantity, resonance occurs. For rotating devices, it is symbolized by omega and expressed in revolutions per second. Name this property referring to the number of occurrences of a repeating event per unit time, which is measured in Hertz.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This force allows accelerated rolling motion down an incline by producing a net torque on the object. In general, this nonconservative force is equal to the normal force times mu, its namesake coefficient, and it converts kinetic energy into internal energy. For a given object, the kinetic variety is less than the static type. Name this force between surfaces that opposes the motion of an object.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: One of these devices with a length of 994 millimeters can be used to measure a second. The precession of one of these devices proved that the Earth rotates, according to Foucault. Christian Huygens used these devices to make more accurate (*) grandfather clocks. Name this device consisting of a mass suspending from a pivot, from which it swings back and forth.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This law was first derived by Benoit Clapeyron, and its namesake constant is equal to the Boltzmann constant multiplied by Avogadro's number, which equals approximately 8.3 joules per mole Kelvin. A modification of this law takes into account attractive forces and particle volume and is named for (*) van der Waals. It can be thought of as a combination of Avogadro's, Boyle's, and Charles's laws. Name this equation of state approximating behavior of its namesake state of matter, often represented as PV equals nRT.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: It was postulated after the discovery of several heavy particles thought to be formed by strong nuclear reactions but did not interact with matter via that force. Having only integer values, it is always conserved in strong nuclear reactions that created the heavy particles but not in the weak interactions that cause their decay. Since it must be conserved, heavy particles can only be produced in pairs where the net value is zero, a process called associated production. Identify this quantum property, first proposed by Nishijima and Gell-Mann.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: In fluids, this quantity can be considered equivalent to energy per volume. If Bernoulli’s principle is expressed with all the terms in distance squared per time squared, this quantity is divided by density, and an increase in this quantity has the same type of impact as an increase in energy. Integrating this with respect to volume gives work, and a calculation of enthalpy involves multiplying this times volume and adding the result to internal energy. This is commonly defined as force per area, and it varies inversely with volume in the ideal gas law. Name this quantity that can be measured in pascals, bars, or atmospheres.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This quantity is expressed in the Gell-Mann-Nishijima formula in terms of baryon number, strangeness, and isospin. There are “hyper” types of this associated with both the strong and weak nuclear forces. The derivative of the density of this quantity with respect to time equals the opposite of the flux of current density. The Faraday constant is equal to the fundamental value of this times Avogadro’s constant; that fundamental value was measured by Robert Millikan’s oil-drop experiment, and can be divided by three for quarks. Name this quantity that may be positive or negative, measured in coulombs.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: In standard units, this force's namesake constant equals 6.67 times ten to the negative eleventh power. This force's magnitude is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two objects. On earth it causes objects to accelerate at 9.81 meters per second squared. It acts more strongly on objects of greater mass. Name this fundamental force that causes objects to fall to the ground.

questions.subject: IB Chinese Ab Initio
questions.question: This Chinese dynasty, known for its contributions to art, literature, and philosophy, ruled from 1368 to 1644. Name this dynasty.

questions.subject: Geography
questions.question: One of its major southeastern towns is found on the Hyblaei Hills, and much of its agriculture takes place on the Plain of Catania. Madonie Park is a major preserve in its north, and this home to such provinces as Enna and Raguse has such major urban areas as Noto. The autonomous region dominated by this territory also includes Pelagie, Panteleria, Egadi, and Lipari. Name this home to Mount Etna and Syracuse, an island found across the Strait of Messina from the city of Reggio on the southwest of the mainland of Italy.

questions.subject: IB Mathematics
questions.question: This theorem states that any continuous function on a closed interval [a, b] is uniformly continuous on that interval. Name this theorem named after a German mathematician.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This physical quantity represents the product of an object's mass and its velocity. In a closed system, this quantity is conserved. Name this fundamental concept in physics.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: One representation of this quantity is equal to the momentum squared over two times mass, and it is represented in the Lagrangian with a capital T. The equipartition theorem dictates that for molecules in an ideal gas, this quantity is equal to three-halves times the Boltzmann constant times temperature. The change in this quantity is equal to power times time, and inelastic collisions do not conserve this quantity. Name this quantity defined as one-half times the mass times velocity squared, the energy possessed by objects in motion.

questions.subject: IB Psychology
questions.question: According to this theory of emotion, physiological arousal and the experience of emotion occur simultaneously, each triggering the other. This theory contrasts with the James-Lange theory. Name this theory named after two psychologists.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This process occurs in the mitochondria and involves the oxidation of pyruvate molecules to produce carbon dioxide, NADH, FADH2, and ATP. Name this central metabolic pathway.

questions.subject: IB History of the Americas
questions.question: This treaty, signed in 1848, ended the Mexican-American War and ceded a large portion of Mexico's territory to the United States, including present-day California, Arizona, New Mexico, and parts of Utah, Nevada, and Colorado. Name this treaty.

questions.subject: IB Mathematics
questions.question: This mathematical constant, often denoted by the letter 'e', is approximately equal to 2.71828. It is the base of the natural logarithm and appears in many areas of mathematics, including calculus and probability theory. Name this important constant.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This fundamental force is responsible for holding the nucleus of an atom together. It is mediated by particles called gluons. Name this force.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: For a homogenous system, the ratio of the rate of this reaction to that of absorption is the thermal utilization f, which is one of the factors in the four-factor formula. Solid-state actinide detectors for very-high-energy photons use the gamma-induced variety of this reaction. Plotted against atomic number, its usual yield curve is normally hollow, double-humped and symmetric, but can shift right if the inducing particles are highly energetic. It is energetically favorable to the right of iron-56 so power generation methods utilizing it use heavy elements like thorium as fuel. Name this nuclear reaction often accompanied by release of energy and neutrons; the break-up of large nuclei into smaller ones, discovered by Hahn and Meitner.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: Yang and Mills created a theory of this force that is a non-abelian gauge theory. Another theory describing this force has a lattice variety, and that theory describing this force takes place in an SU(3) symmetry group. Pions were believed to carry this force but it is now known that this is mediated by the exchange of (*) gluons. Color confinement is a consequence of this force that is described by quantum chromodynamics, or QCD. Name this force that confines quarks into hadrons, is the most powerful of the four fundamental forces, and holds atomic nuclei together.

questions.subject: IB World Topics
questions.question: This Cuban leader played a pivotal role in the success of the Cuban Revolution, leading to the establishment of his government. What is the name of this influential figure?

questions.subject: IB World Topics
questions.question: During the Cold War, Fidel Castro and Cuba became central figures in this intense geopolitical event, raising concerns worldwide. What is the name of this crisis?

questions.subject: IB Psychology
questions.question: This psychological perspective emphasizes the role of unconscious conflicts and early childhood experiences in shaping behavior and personality. It was founded by Sigmund Freud. Name this perspective.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This organelle is responsible for the synthesis of proteins in eukaryotic cells. It consists of two subunits, one large and one small, and is composed of RNA and protein. Name this cellular structure.

questions.subject: IB History of the Americas
questions.question: This movement, which began in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, advocated for the rights of workers and sought to improve working conditions and wages. It led to the formation of labor unions and the enactment of labor laws. Name this social and political movement.

questions.subject: IB Mathematics
questions.question: This theorem, named after a French mathematician, states that if a function is continuous on a closed interval and differentiable on the open interval, then there exists at least one point in the open interval where the derivative of the function is equal to the average rate of change of the function over the closed interval. Name this theorem.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This physical principle states that the total energy of an isolated system remains constant over time, regardless of internal changes. Name this principle.

questions.subject: IB Psychology
questions.question: This theory, proposed by Albert Bandura, emphasizes the role of observational learning and cognitive processes in shaping behavior. It suggests that individuals can learn new behaviors by observing others and that reinforcement and punishment are not always necessary for learning to occur. Name this theory.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This process, which occurs during cell division, ensures that each daughter cell receives an identical set of chromosomes. It involves the separation of sister chromatids. Name this phase of mitosis.

questions.subject: IB History of the Americas
questions.question: This landmark Supreme Court case, decided in 1954, declared state laws establishing separate public schools for black and white students to be unconstitutional. It overturned the doctrine of 'separate but equal' established by the Plessy v. Ferguson decision. Name this case.

questions.subject: IB World Topics
questions.question: Fidel Castro's political career began with his involvement in opposition movements against this Cuban dictator. What is the name of the dictator whose regime Castro opposed?

questions.subject: IB Mathematics
questions.question: This mathematical function, denoted by f prime of x or dy over dx, represents the rate of change of a function with respect to its independent variable. Name this important concept in calculus.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This law states that the pressure of a gas is inversely proportional to its volume at constant temperature. Name this law named after a French chemist.

questions.subject: IB Psychology
questions.question: This cognitive bias refers to the tendency to rely on information that is readily available, rather than considering all relevant information when making judgments. Name this bias.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This type of cellular transport involves the movement of molecules or ions against their concentration gradient, typically using energy from ATP. Name this process.

questions.subject: IB History of the Americas
questions.question: This American president, who served from 1933 to 1945, implemented the New Deal policies to address the Great Depression and led the United States during World War II. Name this president.

questions.subject: IB Mathematics
questions.question: This geometric shape has all sides of equal length and all angles of equal measure. Name this polygon.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This fundamental particle, discovered in 1932 by Carl Anderson, has the same mass as an electron but opposite charge. Name this particle.

questions.subject: IB Psychology
questions.question: This psychological perspective focuses on the ways in which people perceive, process, and retrieve information. It examines mental processes such as memory, problem-solving, and decision-making. Name this perspective.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This organelle, found in plant cells but not animal cells, is responsible for photosynthesis. It contains chlorophyll and converts light energy into chemical energy. Name this cellular structure.

questions.subject: IB History of the Americas
questions.question: This landmark legislation, signed into law in 1964, outlawed discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin. Name this civil rights act.

questions.subject: IB Chemistry
questions.question: This law states that the total pressure exerted by a mixture of gases is equal to the sum of the partial pressures of each individual gas in the mixture. Name this law.

questions.subject: IB Chemistry
questions.question: This type of chemical bond is formed between two atoms when they share one or more pairs of electrons. Name this bond.

questions.subject: IB Chemistry
questions.question: This process involves the conversion of a solid directly into a gas without passing through the liquid state. Name this process.

questions.subject: IB Chemistry
questions.question: This law, named after a French chemist, states that the mass of the products in a chemical reaction is equal to the mass of the reactants. Name this law.

questions.subject: IB Chemistry
questions.question: This branch of chemistry deals with the study of the rates of chemical reactions and the factors that affect them. Name this branch of chemistry.

questions.subject: IB Analysis and Approaches
questions.question: This theorem, formulated by a French mathematician in the 17th century, states that if a function is continuous on a closed interval and differentiable on the open interval, then there exists at least one point in the open interval where the derivative of the function is equal to the average rate of change of the function over the closed interval. Name this theorem, which is a special case of the Mean Value Theorem.

questions.subject: IB Analysis and Approaches
questions.question: This mathematical concept, often used in calculus, represents the instantaneous rate of change of a function at a specific point. It is defined as the limit of the average rate of change of the function as the interval approaches zero. Name this fundamental concept in calculus.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This fundamental law of physics, formulated by Sir Isaac Newton in the 17th century, states that every object persists in its state of rest or uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by an external force. It provides the foundation for understanding the motion of objects under the influence of forces. Name this law.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This physical quantity, commonly represented by the symbol 'F', is defined as the product of an object's mass and its acceleration. It is measured in units of Newtons. Name this fundamental concept in physics.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: In the context of nuclear physics, what term is used to describe the process by which a heavy nucleus splits into two or more smaller nuclei, releasing a large amount of energy?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: When a wave encounters a surface that cannot absorb its energy, it bounces back. What is the term for this phenomenon in physics?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: When two waves of the same frequency and amplitude are in phase (crest aligns with crest), what term is used to describe the resulting wave?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: In the context of nuclear reactions, what type of radiation consists of high-energy photons and has no mass or charge?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: What is the name of the law that states the pressure of a gas is inversely proportional to its volume, provided the temperature and quantity of gas remain constant?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: What is the name of the process by which an unstable atomic nucleus loses energy by emitting radiation, such as alpha or beta particles?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: What is the SI unit of electric charge?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: In the context of optics, what term describes the bending of light as it passes from one medium to another, caused by a change in its speed?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This subatomic particle, discovered in 1897 by J.J. Thomson, is negatively charged and is a fundamental constituent of atoms. What is the name of this particle?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: In the study of waves, what term is used to describe the maximum displacement from equilibrium in a wave?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: In the context of electric circuits, what is the term for a circuit element that resists the flow of electric current?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: According to the wave equation, what is the product of the frequency and wavelength of a wave?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: What is the term for the process by which two nuclear particles combine to form a heavier nucleus, releasing energy in the process?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: In the context of classical mechanics, what is the term for a force that opposes the relative motion or tendency of motion between two surfaces in contact? This force is influenced by factors such as the nature of the surfaces and the normal force acting between them.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: Examine the concept of momentum in classical mechanics. What is the term for the product of an object's mass and its velocity? According to Newton's second law, the rate of change of this quantity is equal to the net force acting on the object.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This quantity, symbolized by 'W', represents the amount of energy transferred to or from a system as a result of a force acting over a distance. What is this concept in the realm of classical mechanics?

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This programming concept involves breaking down a complex problem into smaller, more manageable subproblems, which are then solved individually. It is often used to simplify the design and implementation of algorithms and programs. Name this problem-solving approach.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: When an object moves along a circular path at a constant speed, this force directed towards the center of the circle is responsible for keeping the object in its circular motion. What is the term for this force?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: In the study of waves, the distance between successive peaks or troughs of a wave is defined as what?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This fundamental quantity in mechanics is defined as the rate of change of velocity of an object. What is the term for this quantity?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: In the field of optics, this phenomenon occurs when light waves spread out as they pass through a narrow opening or around an obstacle, leading to the bending of the waves. What is this phenomenon?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This quantity, measured in joules, is defined as the capacity to do work or transfer heat. What is the term for this fundamental concept in thermodynamics?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: In nuclear physics, this term refers to the time required for half of a radioactive substance to undergo decay. What is this term?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: In the realm of classical mechanics, this quantity is defined as the force acting on an object per unit area. What is the term for this physical quantity?

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: In the context of nuclear physics, this type of decay involves the emission of an alpha particle from the nucleus. What is the term for this type of radioactive decay?

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This data structure organizes data in a hierarchical manner, with each node having at most two children. It is commonly used to implement binary search trees and is an essential concept in computer science and programming. Name this data structure.

questions.subject: IB Analysis and Approaches
questions.question: This mathematical concept, named after a German mathematician, represents the total area under a curve between two points on a graph. It is often used to find the cumulative effect or total quantity of a changing quantity. Name this concept in calculus.

questions.subject: IB Analysis and Approaches
questions.question: This mathematical principle, named after a French philosopher and mathematician, states that the total number of ways to choose a subset of objects from a larger set is given by the binomial coefficient. It is often used in combinatorics and probability theory. Name this principle.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This physical quantity, represented by the symbol 'p', is defined as the product of an object's mass and its velocity. It is a vector quantity, meaning it has both magnitude and direction. Name this fundamental concept in physics.

questions.subject: IB Physics
questions.question: This fundamental law of physics, named after a British physicist, states that the force experienced by a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is proportional to the current, the length of the wire, and the strength of the magnetic field. Name this law.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This programming paradigm involves organizing code into reusable components called objects, which interact with each other to perform tasks. It promotes modularity, encapsulation, and code reuse. Name this programming paradigm.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This data structure, commonly used to implement LIFO (Last In, First Out) behavior, allows elements to be added or removed only from one end. It follows the principle of Last In, First Out. Name this data structure.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This programming language, developed by Sun Microsystems, is commonly used for building enterprise-level applications, web services, and mobile apps. It is known for its platform independence and object-oriented features. Name this programming language.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This programming language, often used for system programming and embedded systems development, was developed by Dennis Ritchie at Bell Labs in the early 1970s. It is known for its efficiency and low-level control over hardware. Name this programming language.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This sorting algorithm, named after a Hungarian-American mathematician, works by repeatedly swapping adjacent elements if they are in the wrong order. It has an average and worst-case time complexity of O(n^2). Name this sorting algorithm.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This programming concept involves breaking down a complex problem into smaller, more manageable subproblems, which are then solved individually. It is often used to simplify the design and implementation of algorithms and programs. Name this problem-solving approach.

questions.subject: IB Computer Science
questions.question: This programming concept, often used in object-oriented programming, refers to the bundling of data and methods that operate on that data into a single unit. It promotes encapsulation and information hiding. Name this concept.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This physiological process, often referred to as 'the body's thermostat', helps regulate body temperature by increasing blood flow to the skin and promoting sweating when the body overheats, and by conserving heat through vasoconstriction and shivering when the body is cold. Name this process.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This sports psychology concept, named after a Russian physiologist, refers to the state of optimal functioning where an athlete is fully immersed in their activity, characterized by complete absorption, heightened focus, and a distorted sense of time. Name this concept.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This sports science principle, often applied in strength training, states that muscles adapt to the specific demands placed upon them. It suggests that to improve performance, training must progressively overload the muscles by increasing the intensity, duration, or frequency of exercise. Name this principle.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This sports science concept, often referred to as 'the gas tank of the body', represents the maximum amount of oxygen that an individual can utilize during intense exercise. It is measured in milliliters of oxygen per kilogram of body weight per minute. Name this concept.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This cellular organelle, often referred to as the 'powerhouse of the cell', is responsible for generating adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the primary energy currency of the cell, through the process of cellular respiration. Name this organelle.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This process, occurring in the chloroplasts of plant cells, converts light energy into chemical energy, producing glucose and oxygen as byproducts. Name this process.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This genetic disorder, caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21, is characterized by intellectual disability, developmental delays, distinctive facial features, and other health problems. Name this disorder.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This type of cell division, occurring in sexually reproducing organisms, results in the formation of haploid gametes from diploid germ cells. Name this process.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This sports science concept, often referred to as 'the point of no return', represents the intensity of exercise beyond which the body can no longer meet the demands for oxygen and anaerobic metabolism predominates. It is often associated with the buildup of lactic acid and the onset of muscle fatigue. Name this concept.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This sports science principle, often applied in training programs, states that the physiological adaptations resulting from exercise are specific to the type of activity performed and the muscles involved. It suggests that training should mimic the movements and energy systems used in the athlete's sport. Name this principle.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This sports psychology concept, named after a Russian psychologist, refers to the process of mentally rehearsing or visualizing an athletic performance in order to improve skill execution, reduce anxiety, and enhance confidence. Name this concept.

questions.subject: IB Sports Science
questions.question: This biomechanical principle, often applied in sports technique analysis, states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. It helps explain how forces are generated and transferred during movement. Name this principle.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This cellular process, occurring in prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, involves the synthesis of RNA from a DNA template. It is the first step in gene expression and plays a crucial role in protein synthesis. Name this process.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This cellular structure, found in plant cells but not animal cells, provides structural support and rigidity to the cell, as well as protection and regulation of cell shape. It is composed of cellulose fibers and other polysaccharides. Name this structure.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This genetic disorder, caused by a mutation in the CFTR gene, affects the respiratory, digestive, and reproductive systems, leading to thick, sticky mucus buildup in the lungs, pancreas, and other organs. Name this disorder.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This process, occurring during cell division, ensures that each daughter cell receives an equal and complete set of chromosomes. It involves the separation of sister chromatids and the formation of two genetically identical daughter cells. Name this process.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This biological concept, named after an English naturalist, refers to the process by which organisms with advantageous traits are more likely to survive and reproduce, leading to the gradual change in populations over time. Name this concept.

questions.subject: IB Biology
questions.question: This type of symbiotic relationship, in which both organisms benefit from the association, is exemplified by the relationship between nitrogen-fixing bacteria and leguminous plants. Name this type of relationship.
